content.raw:
humm I think we shouldn't be using SRC-specific information on the profile page, because this page is available to all users, even if they're not participating on SRC.

This is being used to determine who is able to see the widget to create a new config, right? At the portal, the [condition](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/src/9af8fcab50139c831309e5029bffa2c32bfe4c2e/server/metric_configs.js?fileviewer=file-view-default#metric_configs.js-137) for being able to create a new config is having write permission to the `metrics-configs` resource. It would be more accurate to determine who sees the widget by checking who has permissions to that resource. You can see [examples](#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/src/48b5ffeb4c3e924b8026d50ff5d49694b78d40cc/app/elements/cs-s3keys/cs-s3keys.html?fileviewer=file-view-default#cs-s3keys.html-196) of how this is done for other widgets using the `cancreate` variable.
content.html:
humm I think we shouldn't be using SRC-specific information on the profile page, because this page is available to all users, even if they're not participating on SRC.

This is being used to determine who is able to see the widget to create a new config, right? At the portal, the condition for being able to create a new config is having write permission to the metrics-configs resource. It would be more accurate to determine who sees the widget by checking who has permissions to that resource. You can see examples of how this is done for other widgets using the cancreate variable.

content.raw: I will take this off `cs-app` and `cs-profile` and use the permissions that way. I will use it in both creation and edit. Thanks!
content.html: I will take this off cs-app and cs-profile and use the permissions that way. I will use it in both creation and edit. Thanks!

content.html: Suggestion: place some of these fields side-by-side to make better use of space

content.raw: I think the meaning of grantee inside the edit dialog can be a bit confusing. The instance hours field is filled with information from the server, but grantee isn't, right? The impression it gives is that if I erase the identity which is currently there, I would be revoking that identity's permission.

The impression it gives is that if I erase the identity which is currently there, I would be revoking that identity's permission.

content.raw: I understand. Maybe having it in a similar way to `s3keys` could be better. This way we can have a subheader "Edit" and another subheader "Share", with an input text field and an "Admin" checkbox. If necessary, we could also show who has permissions over it, as it is done in the keys' "Shared with" subheader. What do you think?
content.html: I understand. Maybe having it in a similar way to s3keys could be better. This way we can have a subheader "Edit" and another subheader "Share", with an input text field and an "Admin" checkbox. If necessary, we could also show who has permissions over it, as it is done in the keys' "Shared with" subheader. What do you think?

content.raw:
I feel a bit uneasy about doing this in two steps (one request to create the resource, wait for response, then another request to share it). This is how most of the code in SASC works, and it has caused several problems. If the user refreshes the page before getting this reply for example, the config will never be shared. In general, we're trying to move logic away from the browser.

I see two alternative ways of doing this:

1. Do the sharing on the server side the moment the resource is created, this requires modifying the `POST /metrics/configs` route
1. Have the user do it in two steps on the GUI. First you click a button to create the resource, then you click another button to share it. This is how other resources like machine types, s3 keys and teams work.
content.html:
I feel a bit uneasy about doing this in two steps (one request to create the resource, wait for response, then another request to share it). This is how most of the code in SASC works, and it has caused several problems. If the user refreshes the page before getting this reply for example, the config will never be shared. In general, we're trying to move logic away from the browser.

I see two alternative ways of doing this:

  1. Do the sharing on the server side the moment the resource is created, this requires modifying the POST /metrics/configs route
  2. Have the user do it in two steps on the GUI. First you click a button to create the resource, then you click another button to share it. This is how other resources like machine types, s3 keys and teams work.

content.raw: Modifying the `POST /metrics/configs` route would be a better approach. That means that new created resources would be shared with the admin group automatically upon creation. I'll check how to do that.
content.html: Modifying the POST /metrics/configs route would be a better approach. That means that new created resources would be shared with the admin group automatically upon creation. I'll check how to do that.

content.raw: Ger: if you are going to update the server side code, maybe instead of hardcoding the admin you could  instead grant to the group listed by the user in the extra input field. This group name could be an extra field (optional) in the post request

What do you think about this @chapulina ?

content.raw:
I addressed your comments @chapulina . Some of the changes include:

* The admin is no longer passed explicitly into the Profile.
* The Metrics element was modified to make better use of horizontal space.
* As done in [this PR](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/pull-requests/86/grant-permission-to-optional-admin/diff), an additional `admin_indentity` is passed upon the creation of the metrics, and granting permissions to it. This is only for the creation of Metrics and thus avoiding granting permissions on callbacks.
* The "Grantee" field in the Edit Dialog was modified. Now it is given permission in a similar way done in the s3keys: Stating username, admin permissions and then sharing it.

Screenshots:
![screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478021512.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/3514518426-screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478021512.png)
![screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478390058.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/2637798908-screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478390058.png)
![screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478403438.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/154834193-screencapture-localhost-8080-profile-1495478403438.png)
content.html:
I addressed your comments @chapulina . Some of the changes include:

  • The admin is no longer passed explicitly into the Profile.
  • The Metrics element was modified to make better use of horizontal space.
  • As done in this PR, an additional admin_indentity is passed upon the creation of the metrics, and granting permissions to it. This is only for the creation of Metrics and thus avoiding granting permissions on callbacks.
  • The "Grantee" field in the Edit Dialog was modified. Now it is given permission in a similar way done in the s3keys: Stating username, admin permissions and then sharing it.

Screenshots:

Since we're providing an interface to grant permission, we should probably also offer a way to see the current permissions and to revoke permissions.

Maybe we can reuse some code from machine types, s3keys and teams.
